stories.headline: Donors give $100,000 to St. Joseph Center after fire
stories.summary: Community support has raised $100,000 for the St. Joseph Center of Arkansas after it suffered damaging fire and wildfire-related destruction. Efforts to remove debris and stabilize the historic building are ongoing, with construction crews working to rebuild. The center, built in 1910 and listed on the National Register of Historic Places, continues to receive aid to recover from this disaster.

stories.headline: Israel to allow aid delivery into Gaza
stories.summary: Israel announced it will allow a limited amount of humanitarian aid into Gaza following a three-month blockade, amid military and security concerns. The move comes after discussions and warnings about a potential security crisis and starvation risks in Gaza. Aid deliveries are authorized but will be restricted to basic amounts of food, as military tensions continue in the region.

stories.headline: Biden gets prostate cancer diagnosis
stories.summary: President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, with doctors noting the disease has spread to his bones. He was seen by doctors following urinary symptoms and a prostate nodule detection. The President, along with his medical team, is reviewing treatment options for this hormone-sensitive cancer that is known for aggressive features.

stories.headline: Owners air concern over new law
stories.summary: Natural gas operators in Fayetteville expressed concern that a new law might negatively impact royalty payments. Representatives and producers worry that a cloud on new drilling and changes to royalty rights could affect the industry, sparking debate with lawmakers and industry experts about the future financial and operational impact in the region.

stories.headline: Bill takes aim at key power of US courts
stories.summary: A new bill aims to curb enforcement of contempt findings by US courts, raising questions about the government’s authority to enforce rulings. The proposal faces uncertainty on whether it can pass the House and the Senate, especially amid ongoing power struggles involving the Trump administration and efforts to limit court powers related to immigration enforcement.

stories.headline: Biden eyes options after cancer news
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with a relatively aggressive form of prostate cancer, with the disease spreading to his bones. Biden and his family are reviewing treatment options, with his office noting the diagnosis requires effective management. The family remains hopeful as they consider next steps after receiving the news.

stories.headline: Scientists help link tribe to famed site
stories.summary: Indigenous New Mexicans connected to ancient trading society through DNA mapping at Chaco Canyon demonstrate significant historical insights. Researchers from Southern Methodist University and other institutions have linked a federally recognized tribe to the site, marking a major contribution to understanding the region's history and genetics.

stories.headline: Paying trainees may get funding
stories.summary: Lawmakers are considering supporting a residency model for teachers that includes paying trainees during their classroom experience. The initiative is receiving backing as it promises to improve educator quality by providing hands-on experience and financial support before new teachers take full responsibility in classrooms.

stories.headline: Program lets families map futures together
stories.summary: A Spanish-language program helps families navigate the school system by teaching parents and children about educational policies, community resources, and development tools. The Community Action Network program at Bachman Lake Together aims to empower families in the 75220 ZIP code with leadership skills and a collaborative approach to education.

stories.headline: Whispers of Scheffler slide are premature
stories.summary: Dallas pro Scottie Scheffler reasserts his dominance in the PGA Tour with solid performances, quelling rumors of a decline. After an 8-shot win at the PGA Championship, Scheffler remains confident in his game, attributing his success to consistency rather than a peak or drop.

stories.headline: Trump’s IVF advocacy risks clash with pro-life allies
stories.summary: President Trump is advocating for expanding access to in vitro fertilization (IVF), but his position risks alienating pro-life conservatives who oppose the fertility industry's lack of regulation on embryo disposal. The White House has protected Trump’s IVF plans from premature controversy, yet the debate raises ethical concerns regarding the fate of unused embryos and the direction of IVF within the pro-life community.

stories.headline: Cease-fire hopes hinge on Trump-Putin talks after massive Russian drone assault on Kyiv
stories.summary: Diplomatic efforts between U.S., Ukrainian, and Russian leaders are intensifying following a massive Russian drone attack on Kyiv, which resulted in heavy damage. Officials see an opportunity for peace talks involving President Trump and President Vladimir Putin, aiming to reduce hostilities after nearly two years of warfare. Key figures including Ukraine’s President Zelensky and U.S. officials are engaged in discussions to explore a possible cease-fire and peaceful resolution.

stories.headline: Trump rages after justices block rapid deportations
stories.summary: President Trump criticized the Supreme Court’s decision to block rapid deportations under the Aliens Enemies Act, arguing that migrants should not receive extended time to challenge deportations. The high court’s ruling was seen as a setback for the Trump administration’s immigration enforcement policies, delaying removals and complicating efforts to address illegal immigration through expedited processes.

stories.headline: Biden decline casts shadow over 2028 hopefuls
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden’s cognitive decline is causing concern among Democrats and casting doubt on the 2028 presidential hopefuls who must now navigate a landscape shaped by his legacy. Biden’s health and mental acuity have become key issues of public trust, with some allies distancing themselves. Meanwhile, Attorney General Merrick Garland faces criticism for allegedly shielding evidence related to Biden’s mental state during an October 2023 interview, further intensifying political tensions.

stories.headline: ‘A United Church’
stories.summary: Chicago-born Pope Leo XIV has been installed as the first pontiff from the U.S. This historic event is bringing a sense of unity to the church and holds special personal meaning for those who knew him in Chicago.

stories.headline: Cubs pull off sweep in NLDS
stories.summary: The Chicago Cubs have successfully swept their opponents in the National League Division Series, showcasing outstanding performance and advancing further in the baseball postseason.

stories.headline: Chicago saw 6.5% more visitors in 2024, but city remains behind pre-pandemic level
stories.summary: Visitor numbers to Chicago increased by 6.5% in 2024 compared to previous years, although the total tourist count has not yet reached the levels seen before the COVID-19 pandemic.

stories.headline: Biden Weighs Treatment Options for Aggressive Form of Prostate Cancer
stories.summary: President Biden is currently considering various treatment options for his aggressive prostate cancer, as reported in the latest health news covering his medical condition and potential impact on his leadership.

stories.headline: Ithaca plans to update homeless encampments
stories.summary: Ithaca city officials have recently approved an updated homeless encampment enforcement policy aimed at improving living conditions for people experiencing homelessness. The new policy allows temporary camping in city-owned areas such as Walmart's Southwest business district, known as "The Jungle," and focuses on enhancing quality of life through sanitation, waste management, safety measures, on-site healthcare access, mental health, and substance abuse counseling. The update incorporates community feedback from public consultations and forums held over the past year.

stories.headline: Unusual pattern noted before hurricane season
stories.summary: An unusual weather pattern has emerged ahead of the Atlantic hurricane season, with no tropical cyclones forming anywhere in the Northern Hemisphere as of May 16, 2025. Meteorologist Phil Klotzbach from Colorado State University noted this low activity is due to a unique wind pattern creating anti-cyclonic flow not supportive of storm formations. Climatologist Ryan Maue suggested an early season tropical storm is possible in the Eastern Pacific and a quiet pattern is expected for the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico. Historically, the Northern Hemisphere averages 3.5 storms by this time of year, but there have been five previous years since 1973 with no named storms at this point.

stories.headline: 2 dead after ship hits Brooklyn Bridge
stories.summary: A Mexican Navy tall ship crashed into the Brooklyn Bridge on May 17, killing two sailors and injuring 19 others. The vessel lost power just before the crash at around 8:20 p.m. ET. Out of the 277 people on board, two died and 19 were hurt, with two in critical condition. Authorities, including New York Mayor Eric Adams, expressed gratitude to first responders and hope for all on board. The incident involved the Mexican Navy tall ship Cuauhtémoc, used for sail training and goodwill tours to other nations.

stories.headline: Trump's pick for top federal prosecutor in South Florida nears Senate confirmation
stories.summary: Miami-Dade County Judge Jason Reding Quiñones is close to being confirmed as the top federal prosecutor in South Florida. The Senate Judiciary Committee voted mostly along party lines in favor of Pos. Quiñones, who could be confirmed by the GOP-controlled Senate in the coming weeks. His nomination is seen as a significant step amid political disputes between Democrats and Republicans.

stories.headline: 'Redundant agency': Child welfare groups doubt Hope Florida's claims on foster care
stories.summary: Child welfare groups have expressed skepticism about Hope Florida's claims regarding its impact on foster care. While Hope Florida asserts it has helped reduce the number of children in foster care by 7,000 during Hurricane Milton, critics argue the program's claims are exaggerated or false. Concerns were also raised about overlaps with existing programs and the moral support role of the nonprofit that runs foster care operations in several Florida counties.

stories.headline: Haitian-American legacy into each bottle
stories.summary: Singer and entrepreneur Melky Jean, sister of Wyclef Jean, has launched her Supreme Spirits brand with the Saint Sauveur Haitian Heritage 1972 rum. The brand pays tribute to the 1972 arrival of seaborne Haitian refugees in South Florida. Jean combines her background in music with her passion for spirits, aiming to share Haitian roots and culture through her rum. She debuted her rum at the Miami Grand Prix and plans further events highlighting Haitian heritage.

stories.headline: Top Florida officials ramp up criticism of judge who blocked state immigration law
stories.summary: Governor Ron DeSantis and other top Florida officials have increased their criticism of a federal judge who blocked the enforcement of a state immigration law targeting undocumented immigrants. The judge, Kathleen Williams, has faced censure for her decision. Her ruling was characterized as 'wrongly' concluded by critic officials, while the judge was appointed by former President Barack Obama and argued against the state's authority to enforce the law.

stories.headline: MESSAGE OF UNITY
stories.summary: Pope Leo XIV officially begins his papacy with an inaugural Mass that emphasized unity and healing in a polarized Catholic Church and world. The event drew around 200,000 attendees including pilgrims, presidents, patriarchs, and princes. Pope Leo appeared during the Mass wearing symbolic items representing his new role and the global reach of the Church.

stories.headline: PEDAL FOR A PURPOSE
stories.summary: Micah Hurd is greeted by volunteers holding medals Sunday during the annual 'Rush to Crush Cancer' bike ride on the South Side. More than 1,000 participated in this event, which raises money for cancer research.

stories.headline: Bipartisan legislation targets drug cartels
stories.summary: U.S. Senators Dave McCormick and Mark Kelly introduced bipartisan legislation aimed at combating Mexican drug cartels and fentanyl trafficking into Pennsylvania and the U.S. The bill demands the State Department to develop a strategic approach including milestones and tracking results to boost U.S. security capacity and tackle corruption in Mexico's anti-drug efforts.

stories.headline: 2 heated contests will alter contour
stories.summary: The Allegheny County Council primary elections feature two heated contests that could impact operations at the county jail, property reassessments, and homelessness policies. Various districts including the western and Mon Valley communities are competing, with only Democratic candidates vying for spots against incumbents.

stories.headline: BIDEN DIAGNOSED WITH PROSTATE CANCER
stories.summary: Former president Joe Biden has been diagnosed with a relatively aggressive form of prostate cancer. His office stated the cancer is subject to effective management and that treatments are being considered. Biden and his family are reviewing treatment options ahead of the 2024 election, which he is actively running for.

stories.headline: Former executive sues Newfields for bias, retaliation
stories.summary: Ernest Gause, a former high-ranking Newfields executive, has filed a federal lawsuit against the art and nature campus alleging racial discrimination and retaliation for highlighting institutional malfeasance. The lawsuit was amended in May following Gause's experiences of discrimination over three years. He has engaged in legal processes including filing a charge of discrimination and is proceeding with complaints through the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

stories.headline: Trump won’t be attending ’25 Indy 500, despite invite
stories.summary: President Donald Trump will not attend the 109th Indianapolis 500 despite receiving an open invitation from longtime friend and Indianapolis Motor Speedway owner Roger Penske. This marks the first time since 1911 that a sitting U.S. president has not attended the event. Trump’s decision comes even after his recent praise of Penske’s work on IMS renovations and attendance at other major NASCAR events as a sitting president.

stories.headline: IMS president takes us inside his closet
stories.summary: Doug Boles, president of Indianapolis Motor Speedway and IndyCar, shares a unique look into his life by revealing his collection of over 30 suits, predominantly in shades of blue reflecting his love for the color. This insight is part of a rare personal tour inside his Indianapolis home closet, showing a different side of the racing executive beyond his professional busy schedule in May 2025.

stories.headline: A check on DOJ probes may end
stories.summary: Federal prosecutors across the country may soon be able to indict members of Congress without approval from layers in the Justice Department's Public Integrity section, according to several federal attorneys. The new proposal suggests that such investigations could proceed without consultation of the section's attorneys during key stages of public officials' probes, sparking concerns about oversight and political motivation in cases.

stories.headline: U.S. helped halt Africa's HIV crisis; now Trump's cuts force reckoning
stories.summary: U.S. aid played a significant role in halting the HIV/AIDS epidemic in Eswatini and other African nations through funding and medical support. However, as the U.S. pulls back its aid, locals are questioning the reliance on foreign funds amid potential health risks. The reduction in aid follows cuts initiated during Trump's administration, potentially affecting the progress made over the past two decades in combating HIV/AIDS in the region.

stories.headline: Biden faces aggressive prostate cancer
stories.summary: Former president Joe Biden has been diagnosed with an aggressive form of prostate cancer that has spread to his bones, his office said Sunday. Biden's family is deciding on treatment options for the condition, which is considered manageable. Presidential officials say the cancer appears to be sensitive to hormone therapy allowing for effective management while treatment options are reviewed with his physicians.

stories.headline: Trump officials find a way to evade rules they dislike; Don’t enforce them
stories.summary: Officials in the Trump administration, frustrated by certain regulations like water conservation standards and anti-discrimination laws, often instructed staff not to enforce these rules. This approach reflected a broader intentional strategy to undermine regulations by simply ignoring them, which raises concerns about governance and accountability under the administration's authority.

stories.headline: Leo urges end to division in his first Mass as pope
stories.summary: Pope Leo XIV delivered his inaugural Mass calling for unity and diversity within the church. He emphasized the importance of love and reconciliation, urging followers to move beyond division while also addressing contemporary challenges faced by the Catholic Church.

stories.headline: Israel begins 'extensive' Gaza ground operations
stories.summary: Israeli forces have launched extensive ground operations in northern and southern Gaza as the military said Sunday that airstrikes also continue. Israel's government characterizes the offensive as part of efforts to eliminate terrorist groups in the region, while warning of significant challenges and impacts of the ongoing conflict.

stories.headline: Missing California Woman Is the Face of a Crisis
stories.summary: Emmilie Risling vanished after hitchhiking near a creek in Klamath, and residents are deeply affected by her disappearance amid broader issues faced by indigenous communities and under-resourced search efforts in Northern California.

stories.headline: Crackdown on Unlicensed Bakery Workers in Texas
stories.summary: Owners of a bakery in Texas have been accused of harboring undocumented workers following a federal raid, sparking legal scrutiny and community concerns.

stories.headline: A Haven for Girls' Wrestling
stories.summary: The Lucha Wrestling Club in the Bronx offers a welcoming space for girls interested in wrestling, promoting sports and empowerment in New York City schools.

stories.headline: Data Centers' Costs Spreading
stories.summary: The rising costs of energy consumption by data centers are affecting individuals and small businesses, sparking a new report focused on infrastructure challenges.

stories.headline: Dealing With 'Debanking'
stories.summary: There is political disagreement over bank account closures without warning, and efforts are ongoing to find fair solutions to this emerging issue in Washington.

stories.headline: A Super-Powered Asterisk
stories.summary: An art director discusses typographic elements including the 'Thunderbolts' symbol and related design adjustments in creative work.

stories.headline: Support for Immigrant Artists
stories.summary: A new show celebrates immigrant artists and their contributions, highlighting themes of appreciation and inclusion.

stories.headline: Summer Chill for Travel
stories.summary: Many airlines, hotels, and analysts forecast a downturn in tourism this summer linked to President Trump's policies and ongoing uncertainty.

stories.headline: Bladder Transplant Performed
stories.summary: A medical breakthrough involving the first-ever bladder transplant in humans offers new hope for patients with debilitating conditions.

stories.headline: Help, Not Pink Slip, From A.I.
stories.summary: Experts predict artificial intelligence will augment rather than replace medical jobs, reflecting optimism about technology's role in healthcare.

stories.headline: Mexican Ship Hits Brooklyn Bridge
stories.summary: Emergency workers tended to the Cuauhtémoc, a naval vessel, after it crashed on Saturday night, killing two crew members.

stories.headline: #MeToo Moment in France
stories.summary: A guilty verdict for a famed actor signals progress in France's #MeToo movement, addressing sexual abuse and demanding accountability.

stories.headline: India's Battle With Pakistan
stories.summary: A report highlights ongoing tensions between India and Pakistan, noting recent escalations and veteran insights on the situation.

stories.headline: Harvard Law School's 'Copy' Actually From 1300
stories.summary: A discussion about a Magna Carta version purchased for $27.50 that is actually an original from the year 1300, attracting significant attention and considered a rare historical artifact.

stories.headline: Biden Battling Prostate Cancer That Is Stage 4
stories.summary: President Joe Biden announced a diagnosis of aggressive stage 4 prostate cancer that has spread, describing the prognosis and ongoing medical management including new treatments.

stories.headline: Rising Chorus by Courts: Immigrants Have Rights
stories.summary: The Supreme Court has supported due process rights for immigrants amid President Trump's aggressive deportation policies, emphasizing constitutional protections even for non-citizens.

stories.headline: N.J. Transit and Union Reach Deal to End Strike
stories.summary: An agreement has been reached to end New Jersey's statewide transit strike after 40 years, with trains set to return to service on Tuesday, benefiting commuters and resolving labor disputes.

stories.headline: Calling for a Diverse and United Church
stories.summary: Over 1,000 people gathered at Pope Leo XIV before his inaugural Mass on Sunday, emphasizing unity and brotherhood within the church community.

stories.headline: Israel Expands Attacks In Gaza
stories.summary: The Israeli military announced a Sunday operation to launch extensive ground attacks throughout northern and southern Gaza Strip, aiming to move farther into the region and seize more land amid ongoing conflict, pressuring Hamas and intensifying a humanitarian crisis.

stories.headline: Art installation honors memory of beloved fishing shacks
stories.summary: Artist Haley Nannig's weekend exhibit, "Living Edges," honors the history of Fisherman's Point shacks in South Portland. The installation features five silk paintings that trace the shacks' historic imagery from the 19th century through their disappearance by early 2024. Nannig's art is meant to advocate for the future of the Willard Beach spot and inspire reflection on how the area might continue to evolve, emphasizing the community's connection to the fishing structures.

stories.headline: Plan to loosen federal habitat protection viewed as threat to iconic Maine wildlife
stories.summary: The Trump administration's proposal to weaken federal habitat protections for imperiled plants and animals in Maine has raised alarms among environmentalists. They warn the changes could threaten species the state has worked to safeguard, including bald eagles, wolves, and Florida manatees. Environmental groups have promised to fight the changes in court if implemented. On May 12, a group of Democratic senators questioned the Trump administration's analysis of the rule's impact on wildlife.

stories.headline: Biden diagnosed with ‘aggressive form’ of prostate cancer
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, identified after a prostate nodule was found during a routine cancer screening. Doctors characterize the cancer as an aggressive form known as Gleason score 9, indicating high risk. Biden's medical team states that while the cancer is very treatable and not curable, the treatments may be hormone-sensitive and are being carefully reviewed. The diagnosis underscores the challenges of prostate cancer that can spread and require complex management.

stories.headline: Proposed bill would seal some criminal records
stories.summary: A Senate bill introduced earlier this month aims to automatically seal certain criminal records, sparking debate between supporters and opponents. The legislation would give people with a criminal history a second chance by sealing records that meet specific statutory requirements, unless prosecutors oppose after a hearing. The bill, LD 1911, sponsored by Senator Rachel Talbot Ross and others, includes provisions for misconduct ranging from misdemeanors to serious crimes, with some exceptions. Supporters argue the bill helps restore opportunity, while opponents want more research and caution about blanket approaches.

stories.headline: Medicaid cuts could be harmful
stories.summary: Texas children's hospitals are concerned about potential negative impacts of proposed Medicaid budget cuts on their finances and ability to serve patients. The Children's Hospital Association of Texas highlights worries about reduced funding affecting care for families and vulnerable populations. Recent federal reports estimate a $912 billion cut to Medicaid, though not as severe as initially feared. The cuts would not include block grants or per capita grants but could still limit the number of people enrolled in Medicaid, a key healthcare fund for low-income children, pregnant women, and people with disabilities.

stories.headline: Softball ace Teagan Kavan regains form in regional win
stories.summary: Teagan Kavan, a noted softball player, has regained her competitive form contributing to a big win in a regional softball event. Her performance marks a strong return to form and is celebrated by her team and supporters. This success highlights her importance to the team and her potential impact in upcoming competitions.

stories.headline: Biden reviews options after getting cancer diagnosis
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with an aggressive form of prostate cancer that has spread to the bone. His family and physicians are reviewing treatment options. Biden had recently ended his reelection bid after a tough presidential campaign. Despite his age and health challenges, Biden remains a prominent figure in politics with broad support from different political groups. His diagnosis has sparked messages of support and wishes for a speedy recovery from political allies and opponents alike.

stories.headline: 'Our system is really broken'
stories.summary: Following a critical Department of Justice report on problems in Texas juvenile prisons, state lawmakers are pursuing harsher measures including sending more children to adult prisons and limiting oversight by youth advocates. Recent legislation such as Senate Bill 1727 and Senate Bill 2693 aim to impose stricter consequences and reduce the ability of watchdog groups to monitor juvenile detention conditions. This comes amid concerns of sexual and physical abuse within juvenile lockups. Advocates express deep concerns about the state of the juvenile justice system.

stories.headline: Manifesto threatened an attack on a fertility clinic
stories.summary: Authorities have identified a 25-year-old suspect in the Palm Springs bombing who was inspired by nihilistic ideations. The suspect allegedly targeted a fertility clinic, injuring four people, in what FBI officials describe as an act of intentional terrorism. Police continue their investigation while urging calm in the community.

stories.headline: Ways to defend climate progress
stories.summary: Legal actions and legislation are increasingly being used to counteract efforts by former President Trump's environmental policies. Experts discuss current strategies involved in defending climate progress after political changes.

stories.headline: Mexico vessel hits Brooklyn Bridge
stories.summary: A Mexican navy sailing ship on a goodwill mission accidentally struck two crew members on the Brooklyn Bridge, causing injuries. The incident occurred while the ship was sailing under the bridge and is under investigation.

stories.headline: Israel will allow limited Gaza aid
stories.summary: Israel has decided to permit a small amount of food aid into Gaza to help avert a hunger crisis amid ongoing military conflict. This limited concession aims to provide some relief to civilians affected by current hostilities while maintaining overall military objectives.

stories.headline: Hope for housing in Coachella Valley
stories.summary: After years of scarcity, the Coachella Valley is seeing progress in affordable housing development. New units are planned or under construction in all nine desert cities, including mixed income and senior housing. Projects like Aloe Palm Canyon with amenities close to local attractions aim to address the region's growing demand for affordable housing despite its resort town nature.

stories.headline: Edison bonuses went up despite safety issues
stories.summary: Despite safety issues including multiple fires caused by equipment, Southern California Edison executives received pay raises. The state law protecting utilities from liability came with a condition for top executives to face pay cuts if the company's safety record worsened, but Edison still increased bonuses though the number of fires rose significantly. Serious injuries also occurred among employees.

stories.headline: Biden is diagnosed with prostate cancer
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden, 82, has been diagnosed with an aggressive form of prostate cancer that has metastasized to his bones. The diagnosis follows the discovery of a prostate nodule after he experienced urinary symptoms. Biden and his family are reviewing treatment options with his physicians. This marks the first public announcement of a serious health issue for Biden.

stories.headline: Salvadorans are divided over ruler
stories.summary: Victor Barahona was grateful when soldiers began rounding up gang members who had long terrorized his working-class city in El Salvador. However, some critics label President Bukele as an old-school dictator who uses military force to crack down on gangs. Most Salvadorans support the crackdown but also fear the government's authoritarian approach as human rights concerns surface.

stories.headline: Zelenskyy talks with Vance, Rubio
stories.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met with key U.S. officials, including Vice President JD Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio, in Rome to discuss a high-stakes phone call between U.S. President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin about ending the war in Ukraine. Zelenskyy emphasized the need for a full and unconditional ceasefire and shared his concerns about the ongoing conflict and diplomatic efforts.

stories.headline: Cubs complete City Series sweep
stories.summary: The Cubs defeated the White Sox 6-2 in the third game of a series marked by mistakes from the opposing team. This victory secured a sweep of the City Series, much to the delight of Cubs fans.

stories.headline: Biden diagnosed with cancer
stories.summary: The President of the United States has been diagnosed with an aggressive form of prostate cancer. Officials noted that the cancer has spread to the bones, highlighting the seriousness of the illness. The news has implications for national leadership and health concerns.

stories.headline: Officers observed for problem traffic stops before Reed killing
stories.summary: Five tactical officers involved in a fatal shooting of a former basketball player at Westinghouse College Prep were under investigation for problematic traffic stops prior to the incident. The officers were noted for repeated use of excessive force and other violations. The shooting of Reed has sparked scrutiny over police oversight and accountability in Chicago.

stories.headline: Housing nonprofit faces $10M shortfall
stories.summary: The Chicago Low-income Housing Trust Fund is facing a $10 million shortfall in its budget for 2025, which will impact its ability to provide subsidies for low-income renters. This has affected individuals like Adrienne Nelson, who relies on rent subsidies to afford housing. The shortfall is attributed to factors including market conditions, migration, and funding limitations, threatening the housing assistance program's sustainability.

stories.headline: 'I come to you as a brother' - Pope Leo XIV officially begins his papacy with inaugural Mass in St. Peter's Square
stories.summary: Pope Leo XIV held his inaugural Mass in St. Peter's Square, becoming the first American-born pontiff. During the Mass, he called for unity, care for the environment, and peace among nations. Tens of thousands of worshipers gathered in the square to witness the historic event and hear the Pope's message of brotherhood, reconciliation, and hope.

stories.headline: A day at the ‘world’s largest truck stop’
stories.summary: The Iowa 80 Truckstop near Walcott, Iowa, is the world's largest truck stop, featuring numerous amenities such as six fast-food chains, a restaurant, buffet, movie theater, chiropractor, and museum. Sitting along Interstate 80, which spans over 2,900 miles from San Francisco to New Jersey, the truckstop serves a diverse group of truck drivers and offers a unique experience for visitors, highlighting its extensive services and entertainment options.

stories.headline: Afghan refugee faces eviction as resettlements end
stories.summary: A newly arrived Afghan refugee in Iowa faces eviction after Catholic Charities closed its resettlement program that operated for 50 years. Many refugees, including this woman, are struggling to find work and housing as resources diminish. The program was ended due to decreasing demand and challenges during the Trump administration's crackdown on refugee programs. Catholic Charities made the decision to end the program while continuing to help refugee clients in other ways.

stories.headline: Reynolds had wins, losses in session
stories.summary: Governor Kim Reynolds decided not to run for reelection in 2026 but worked hard in the Iowa Legislature's 2025 session to push many priorities, including policies on 'Condition of the State' addressing Medicaid, energy, disaster response, and hands-free driving laws. Despite some proposed bills failing to pass, Reynolds expressed pride in the work done and plans to complete her agenda before leaving office.

stories.headline: Will the ‘flying palace’ come back to county?
stories.summary: There is ongoing debate over whether the controversial $400 million luxurious plane dubbed the 'flying palace', previously used by President Donald Trump, will return to Palm Beach County. Media reports reveal Trump's frequent use of the plane during his presidency and highlight disagreements among critics and supporters regarding the significance of his travels through the Middle East. The plane has been a focal point of discussion especially during the upcoming May presidential travels.

stories.headline: Growth complicates shift to renewable energy
stories.summary: Rising power demand fueled by AI and climate change is complicating the transition to renewable energy sources in the U.S. Experts including Arizona accounting specialist Arun Mani and resource planner Mike Eugenis express concerns about meeting growing energy needs while managing the shift amid industrial challenges. Energy conferences emphasize the tensions between various power priorities and the need to adapt to climate change and technological growth, while also noting uncertainties tied to energy policies under President Donald Trump's administration.

stories.headline: State tells colleges to do checks on safety
stories.summary: Following a mass shooting at Florida State University, the state panel overseeing public universities is urging all colleges to review and improve their security policies this summer. Lockdown challenges encountered by FSU students and teachers during the shooting have prompted calls for better protocols, such as securing classroom doors from the inside. The Florida Board of Governors highlights their ongoing collaboration with university leaders to enhance campus safety and preparedness for potential lockdowns.

stories.headline: Longest, shortest commutes in PBC
stories.summary: Palm Beach County workers experience commutes nearly the same length as before the pandemic, according to the latest data from the U.S. Census Bureau. Despite the challenges of recent years, the average commute time remains close to pre-COVID levels, with slight variation in work-from-home trends and carpooling rates. The annual American Community Survey provides insights into local transit habits and work routines.

stories.headline: Israel expands ground attacks
stories.summary: The Israeli military announced extended ground operations in Gaza Strip aimed at seizing more land as part of an intensified campaign against Hamas and to pressure for a cease-fire. The Israeli government will allow limited food aid into Gaza amid looming starvation concerns. The timing for resumption of aid deliveries remains unclear, while political leaders continue cease-fire talks amid ongoing conflict.

stories.headline: Gas pipeline hopes, challenges reemerge
stories.summary: Massachusetts Governor Maura Healey and other Northeast states leaders present President Trump's proposal to resurrect a controversial pipeline project to address high energy costs in the region. The Constitution Pipeline would carry natural gas from Pennsylvania to New York but faces opposition due to environmental and regulatory challenges, with critics noting the project's potential high costs and risks.

stories.headline: THE HAUNTING FIELDS
stories.summary: Sophy Theam, a survivor of the Khmer Rouge genocide, reflects on the tragic loss and resilience of her family and community in Lowell, where a new exhibit displays haunting images and sculptures depicting the brutal history of the Khmer Rouge regime. The regime's genocidal policies led to millions of deaths from starvation, disease, and execution in Cambodia between 1975 and 1979 under Pol Pot.

stories.headline: Frustration, written in Capitol letters
stories.summary: Some Democrats are responding to President Trump's administration with a renewed tactic of sending letters to demand information and investigations, reflecting frustration over the administration's handling of issues and communication. Senator Chuck Schumer emphasized dissatisfaction with media coverage and the administration's actions, advocating a more direct approach to address ongoing concerns in Congress.

stories.headline: Biden has prostate cancer
stories.summary: President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, a type of cancer that can be aggressive but is often treatable if detected early. This health news raises concerns about his condition and potential treatment but highlights the effectiveness of modern medical options for managing the disease.

stories.headline: ‘It is what it is?’ Belichick facing a blitz of attention.
stories.summary: New England Patriots coach Bill Belichick is under public scrutiny following reports of his 24-year-old girlfriend, Jordon Hudson, formerly a cheerleader and Mrs. Maine USA. The unusual scene of Belichick with Hudson at a public event has drawn attention, stirring discussions about his personal life and professional judgment. Despite the distractions, Belichick remains focused on coaching in the NFL.

stories.headline: HPD adds family violence division
stories.summary: The Houston Police Department has added a Family Violence Division to tackle the rising number of domestic crimes, despite a decline in homicides overall in 2024. Investigators have linked family violence to nearly 25% of the department's 203 homicide investigations at one point in 2024, highlighting the significance of domestic violence in the community.

stories.headline: Nonprofits aim to offset counselor shortages
stories.summary: HISD is collaborating with groups to enhance college readiness by addressing counselor shortages. During College Decision Day celebrations, efforts focused on students making informed choices, with some students and onlookers applauding the support. The issue is noted to affect university enrollment and student outcomes.

stories.headline: Cancer in Biden seen as growing, aggressive
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, which has spread to the bone. His office stated that effective management of the disease is possible, and the President and his family are reviewing treatment options with physicians. The cancer is considered more aggressive but hormone-sensitive, allowing for better management.

stories.headline: Will America be ready for World Cup visitors?
stories.summary: Houston is preparing to host hundreds of thousands of visitors from around the world for the 2026 FIFA World Cup. Experts raise questions about America's ability to receive such a large influx of people, while local hosts are committed to ensuring a safe and smooth experience. The event will be historic as the tournament is co-hosted by Canada, Mexico, and the United States, with Houston's top World Cup planners working to make the event successful and enjoyable.

stories.headline: Assaults Rattle The Crypto Elite
stories.summary: Executives and investors in the cryptocurrency industry are increasingly targeted by abductions and violent robberies. Several incidents involving masked attackers threatening victims to gain access to their properties have been reported globally, raising concerns about security in this high-profile financial sector.

stories.headline: 'Stealthy Wealthy' Are Making Money With Boring Businesses
stories.summary: Many wealthy individuals are generating significant wealth through stable, traditional businesses rather than trendy or high-profile ventures. This phenomenon, dubbed the 'stealthy wealthy,' involves investing in flooring, carpet, and other less glamorous sectors that yield reliable returns and long-term success, challenging perceptions about where fortunes are made.

stories.headline: Russia Steps Up Ukraine Attacks Before Trump Call
stories.summary: Just before a phone call between President Trump and Vladimir Putin, Russia increased military attacks in Ukraine, targeting key regions including Kyiv and an eastern oblast. The escalation includes missile strikes and intensified ground operations, contributing to ongoing conflict tensions. These actions put additional pressure on diplomatic efforts and raise concerns about further regional instability.

stories.headline: Israel Expands Ground Campaign In Gaza
stories.summary: Israel's military activated troops in Gaza for a large ground operation targeting Hamas to demilitarize the region and free hostages. A senior Israeli official said the strike was based on intelligence, focusing on Hamas infrastructure and militants. The military aims to intensify strikes after a deadly Hamas attack killed their leader, with casualties on both sides mounting.

stories.headline: GM Pushed EVs, but Now Aims To Pull Plug on California Rule
stories.summary: General Motors is moving away from its aggressive electric vehicle strategy in the U.S. by seeking to nullify a 2022 California mandate that bans sales of new gasoline-powered cars and trucks by 2035. GM argues the regulation hurts affordability and consumer choice, proposing instead to focus on alternative propulsion technologies and incentives like tax credits for electric vehicle buyers.

stories.headline: Pope Calls for Church Unity in Inaugural Mass
stories.summary: Pope Leo XIV addressed 200,000 people at St. Peter's Square, calling for unity within the Church amidst ongoing global challenges, including the war. The event also included high-profile figures like Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. This inaugural mass emphasized peace and solidarity among the faithful.

stories.headline: Legislature’s time short, list of bills long
stories.summary: Minnesota lawmakers face a tight deadline to pass the state budget and numerous bills before the end of the 2025 legislative session on Monday, with only four out of more than a dozen budget bills passed so far. House DFL Leader Melissa Hortman expressed hope of completing the remaining work in a short special session before Memorial Day. Lawmakers are working swiftly on veterans and military affairs, agriculture, public safety, education, and health services, while navigating political challenges to finalize the budget by the 2025 session deadline.

stories.headline: Social-emotional classes caught in culture wars
stories.summary: Conservative groups criticize social-emotional learning (SEL) classes in Minnesota’s largest school district, arguing the lessons are overly ideological. While supporters emphasize SEL’s importance for student development, critics see it as a vehicle for controversial theories like Critical Race Theory and Common Core. The debate has escalated to the school board level, with ongoing discussions about how to balance educational goals with community values and political perceptions of SEL programs.

stories.headline: Shift in flight paths rattles neighbors
stories.summary: Construction at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport has altered flight paths, increasing airplane noise in parts of Apple Valley, Eagan, and other suburbs. Residents report frequent low-flying planes disrupting the area with noise every three minutes during mid-April. This shift in flight paths is due to new temporary runway closures and re-routing during airport expansion, which is expected to finish by May 23. The increase in noise has led to complaints from neighbors adjusting to the new disturbances.

stories.headline: Tribe, Electric Co-op Clash Over Solar
stories.summary: A dispute is emerging between the Upper Sioux Community and Minnesota Valley Cooperative Light and Power Association over the tribe’s plan to install a solar array to power its new casino and hotel. The dispute centers on state utility regulations and the alleged violation of tribal sovereignty. The tribe argues the solar panels will help disconnect from the state’s electric grid, while the co-op, as the sole provider of electricity, is pushing back, leading to tensions over control and operation of the solar project near Granite Falls, Minnesota.

stories.headline: Israel to allow ‘basic’ aid into Gaza
stories.summary: Amid a new military offensive in Gaza, Israel announced it will allow a limited amount of humanitarian aid into Gaza after nearly three months of blockade. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu described the move as a response to avoid famine during the ongoing conflict. The Israeli military continues its operations while attempting to manage aid delivery to prevent supplies reaching militants. The situation remains tense with ongoing airstrikes, a recent two-month truce broken, and differing expectations between Israel and Hamas regarding ceasefire conditions.

stories.headline: Land swap spurs outrage
stories.summary: As news spread over the weekend of a proposal for the state of Florida to trade 600 acres of preserved land to a private company, locals and lawmakers of both parties expressed disbelief and outrage. The attempt to develop this beloved public land has caused significant public revolt. Republican state representative Kim Kendall has asked the state environmental agency to reveal the company behind the proposal, which is listed as The Upland LLC, a business entity with unclear origins. A committee is scheduled to vote on the land deal amid increasing public scrutiny.

stories.headline: She practiced law in Ukraine. War forced her to start over
stories.summary: Liudmyla Nikohosian, a former lawyer from Ukraine, turned hardship into a new life by opening a nail salon in Pinellas. After fleeing Ukraine due to the 2022 Russian invasion, she transitioned from her legal career to becoming a nail technician through a U.S. humanitarian parole program. She now runs Nails by Mila, creating a new business and life far from the conflict she escaped, supported by friends and programs aiding displaced Ukrainians.

stories.headline: Biden has prostate cancer
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with an aggressive form of prostate cancer, with cancer cells having spread to the bone. This diagnosis indicates a more severe form of the disease, requiring effective management and treatment options. Doctors identified symptoms and a prostate nodule last week. Biden's office confirmed the diagnosis and shared that the president and his family are reviewing treatment options with his physicians.

stories.headline: Turbulent waters potential cause in Brooklyn Bridge ship crash
stories.summary: When a Mexican navy tall ship crashed into the Brooklyn Bridge while maneuvering in turbulent waters, the incident resulted in two sailors killed and 19 injured. The ship struck the bridge during training amidst fast-moving and shifting tides in the East River. Despite hazards being managed by an experienced captain, mistakes led to the collision. An investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board is underway, but the complicated conditions and timing suggest the probe will take months. The crash caused significant damage with the vessel's masts collapsing and blocking a crowded pier.

stories.headline: FAMILY PUSHES FOR ANSWERS
stories.summary: Nearly 40 years after Kim Croft, a 19-year-old cheerleader in Ringgold, was raped, beaten, and strangled to death, her family continues to seek justice as the case remains unsolved. Despite a recently passed Georgia law allowing reexamination of cold cases, the investigation was not reopened by the Catoosa County Sheriff's Office. Kim Croft's sisters, LaVonda Croft Deloney and Cheryl Croft, along with their father Floyd Croft, spoke out about their continued efforts to have the case investigated further. The family disputes earlier accusations that misdirected the investigation and hopes to bring closure to this decades-old tragedy.

stories.headline: Joe Biden diagnosed with cancer
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, his office confirms. The diagnosis came after reports of urinary symptoms that led doctors to discover a nodule on his prostate. The cancer is graded for aggressiveness using a Gleason score, with Biden's score being 9, indicating one of the most aggressive types. Biden and his family are currently reviewing treatment options with his physicians. Prostate cancer is common in older men, but the difficulty of treatment varies based on the cancer's stage and spread.

stories.headline: Trump, courts clash may escalate
stories.summary: Tucked deep in the thousand-plus pages of the multitrillion-dollar budget bill making its way through the Republican-controlled U.S. House is a paragraph curtailing a court's greatest tool for forcing the government to obey its rulings: the power to enforce contempt findings. It remains unclear whether the bill can pass the House in its current form and whether the U.S. Senate would preserve the contempt provision or whether courts would uphold it. The conflict highlights the escalating battle between the Trump administration and the courts, with Republican President Donald Trump raising the stakes by attacking the U.S. Supreme Court for its ruling barring his administration from quickly resuming deportations under an 18th-century wartime law.

stories.headline: State workers say Newsom's plan to halt raises is 'untenable'
stories.summary: California state workers and unions have fiercely criticized Governor Gavin Newsom's proposal to freeze raises, arguing it is unworkable and unfair. The governor aims to use the payroll freeze to address the state's $12 billion deficit and anticipated savings target, but workers feel the agreements reached in negotiations are not being honored. The administration also made clear the state would impose reductions in upcoming months whether an agreement is made or not, escalating tensions with unions and workers.

stories.headline: Shasta County's new election chief sparks controversy
stories.summary: Shasta County's new election chief, Clint Curtis, has drawn scrutiny just weeks into his tenure due to his past background in election interference and political controversy. Curtis was selected and appointed amidst debate over his qualifications and previous claims. The controversy has raised concerns about election integrity as he oversees rural North State county elections.

stories.headline: Authorities probe motive in Palm Springs clinic bombing
stories.summary: Authorities are investigating an intentional bombing outside a fertility clinic in Palm Springs that caused major damage to surrounding blocks. The suspect, identified as Gary Edwards Bartkus, 25, is believed to have died in the blast. The explosion has shaken the community, with officials and local leaders emphasizing the clinic's important role serving families and the LGBTQ+ community. An ongoing investigation is underway to understand the motive and circumstances behind the attack.

stories.headline: WORLD'S STRONGEST MAN COMPETITION CROWNS NEW CHAMP
stories.summary: Champion Rayno Nel from South Africa won the 2025 World's Strongest Man competition held in Old Sacramento. Competing with five spherical stones ranging from 220 to 350 pounds, Nel lifted the platforms in the fastest time, edging out two-time Sacramento winner Tom Stoltman who finished second.

stories.headline: Education Department revokes fine against GCU
stories.summary: The U.S. Department of Education has withdrawn a $37.7 million fine against Grand Canyon University (GCU) and dismissed the case amid the Trump administration's attempt to dismantle the agency. The fine, issued under the Biden administration, was the largest against the private Christian university, which contested the cost allegations for its doctoral programs. The revocation follows a joint stipulation and comes as the Education Department faces scrutiny and potential closure.

stories.headline: Summer gas prices arrive
stories.summary: The traditional summer driving season starting Memorial Day weekend is expected to bring both good and bad news for Arizona motorists as gas prices evolve. Consumers can anticipate changes in fuel costs during this peak travel time, impacting travel budgets statewide.

stories.headline: Town's home prices jump
stories.summary: Carefree, known for its small-town atmosphere and desirable location near metro Phoenix, has seen a significant rise in home prices. Over the last 12 months, the median home price in Carefree surged by 53% to $1,492,500, making it a hotspot for real estate amid growing demand from residents and visitors alike.

stories.headline: Embattled chairman of Arizona's Dem Party suspends his No. 2
stories.summary: The chair of the Arizona Democratic Party suspended a top party official from duties citing potential violations of the party's code of conduct. The suspended official, Kim Khoury, was barred from communication with party staff, press, and caucuses pending a formal investigation into alleged failure to fulfill assigned duties as the party’s No. 2 elected officer.

stories.headline: Fighting invasive grass bite at a time
stories.summary: A pilot grazing project involving Navajo-Churro sheep at Tucson's Sentinel Peak Park aims to combat the invasive buffelgrass, which increases wildfire risk. This first-of-its-kind targeted grazing project, funded by the Arizona Department of Forestry and Fire Management, leverages the grass-eating habits of the sheep to reduce wildfire risk while preserving native vegetation.

stories.headline: Zelenskyy meets US officials in Rome
stories.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met with top U.S. officials and European leaders in Rome ahead of a high-stakes phone call between U.S. President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin on ending the war in Ukraine. Discussions focused on Ukraine's defense efforts and diplomatic negotiations.

stories.headline: Biden diagnosed with aggressive form of prostate cancer
stories.summary: President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with a more aggressive form of prostate cancer but is receiving treatment options that could extend his life. Biden's office stated he is a fighter and optimistic about recovery, while political leaders expressed support. The diagnosis comes as Biden faces ongoing health monitoring.

stories.headline: Court fight over MPRP set to begin
stories.summary: A federal court case is set to begin regarding access to land for environmental surveys for the Maryland Piedmont Reliability Project. The project is slated to open by June 1, 2027, but must receive public approvals. Surveys and community input efforts are underway as legal challenges proceed.

stories.headline: Is Archdiocese of Baltimore defying Vatican court order?
stories.summary: Attorneys for the Archdiocese of Baltimore deny reopening a parish that was previously closed as part of a major realignment, despite a Vatican court order. Experts debate whether the refusal violates the court's ruling. The issue centers on St. Clare parish and broader church consolidation efforts.

stories.headline: Moore’s list of challenges grows longer
stories.summary: Maryland Governor Wes Moore faces a series of crises, including a credit downgrade and ongoing budget shortfalls. Despite billions in aid and new taxes, economic and fiscal challenges remain, compounded by debt and borrowing costs. The state is navigating these issues while addressing legislative priorities.

stories.headline: Trump official: Tariffs may lift Walmart costs
stories.summary: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent acknowledged Walmart may pass along some tariff costs to shoppers amid U.S.-China trade tensions. Bessent urged patience on inflation concerns, noting Walmart's CEO advised tariffs could raise prices but they are monitoring the situation closely as consumer prices rise.

stories.headline: Troubled nursing home company renames 12 of its locations
stories.summary: A dozen nursing homes that were part of the troubled Mission Point Healthcare chain rebranded last month as Intersect Healthcare. The rebranding leaves most of the company's lowest-performing homes under the Mission Point name, while two of the new Intersect Healthcare facilities in Hancock and Grandville are candidates for the federal government's Special Focus Facility program, meant for the worst facilities in the country. The home at Hancock was fined after a COVID-19 outbreak, and the Grandville facility was cited for neglecting a patient last year. Workers at the new Intersect Health facilities declined to say whether Prestige Health purchased the facilities, taken an ownership stake, or simply manages them.

stories.headline: 'THIS IS THE HOUR FOR LOVE'
stories.summary: Since his inauguration as the 267th pope 10 days ago, Leo XIV has warned of profound societal divisions and rallied for peace in a conflict-plagued world.

stories.headline: How homeownership is growing further out of reach
stories.summary: Homeownership is receding further out of reach for most Americans as elevated mortgage rates and rising prices stretch the limits of what buyers can afford. The minimum annual salary a homebuyer now needs to afford a $431,250 home is the national median listing price in April, according to data recently released by Realtor.com. Analysis shows the buyer's housing costs won't exceed 30% of their gross monthly income based on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage and a 6.76% interest rate, with high listings prices requiring wages far above median annual incomes in major metro areas.

stories.headline: Marijuana insiders say tax would strangle the business
stories.summary: The state government has taken notice as marijuana becomes lucrative. Governor Gretchen Whitmer has proposed a 32% tax on wholesale marijuana transactions to generate nearly $470 million annually for roads and infrastructure spending. However, marijuana insiders and a township supervisor argued before lawmakers that the tax will kill the industry, citing already financially burdened businesses and falling average retail costs. The tax would impact a growing number of retailers and businesses amid a stagnant market with shrinking revenues.

stories.headline: Missouri school cancer rates prompt HHS inquiry
stories.summary: U.S. Rep. Sam Graves requested the Department of Health and Human Services to investigate elevated cancer rates at a Liberty elementary school, where multiple teachers have been diagnosed. Graves emphasized the concern for the affected children and staff and sought assistance in uncovering causes behind the troubling number of cases. An independent study is being conducted to identify potential risk factors related to the high cancer rates.

stories.headline: Olathe homeowner battles repeated flooding issues
stories.summary: Kate Guimbelot has faced repeated flooding in her home in the College Meadows neighborhood near College Boulevard and South Woodland Road in Olathe. The floods began shortly after her move in 2016, with major flooding events in 2017 that left ankle-deep water in her finished basement. She has engaged with city stormwater officials and builders to address the flooding, with recommendations made to raise the affected area by 3 feet to mitigate future damage.

stories.headline: Pope Leo XIV delivers inaugural message of ‘love and unity’
stories.summary: Pope Leo XIV delivered a message of 'love and unity' during his inaugural Mass on Sunday, marking the official start of his pontificate. Attending dignitaries included Vice President ID Vance, Secretary of State Marco Rubio, Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. In his sermon, the Pope called for peace within the church and the world amid current discord, hatred, and fear.

stories.headline: Missouri plan to keep Chiefs, Royals stalls; what’s next?
stories.summary: Missouri Gov. Mike Kehoe pushed a funding plan for the Kansas City Chiefs and Royals that could finance up to half the cost of a new stadium or upgrades for one or both teams, but the Senate adjourned without voting on it. Despite past governors of both parties showing willingness to call special sessions for major projects, success is uncertain amid political acrimony.

stories.headline: Microsoft: No evidence its tech used to harm Gazans
stories.summary: Following protests by employees, Microsoft stated that internal and external reviews have found no evidence that its technology was used to target people in Gaza. The company made this assurance ahead of a product-focused Build conference and following a rally at Seattle’s Westlake Park organized against Microsoft’s contract with the Israeli Ministry of Defense. Despite employee concerns and public criticism, Microsoft maintains that its cloud computing system and AI technologies were not used to harm Gazans.

stories.headline: Biden has ‘aggressive’ prostate cancer
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden announced that he was diagnosed with an aggressive form of prostate cancer that has spread to his bones. The diagnosis came after doctors detected a small nodule on his prostate and is characterized by a high Gleason score indicating a more advanced cancer. Biden's office states that the president is undergoing effective management and an appropriate treatment plan for Stage 4 prostate cancer.

stories.headline: Gluesenkamp Perez faces leftist heat over her centrist approach
stories.summary: Rep. Marie Gluesenkamp Perez, the only Democrat running for federal or statewide office in Washington to carry a traditionally Republican district, is facing criticism from within her party for not taking a tougher stance against the Trump administration. Some demand she adopt a more progressive approach, while others credit her centrist politics for her electoral success. Her standing will be determined by voters in the next midterm elections amidst growing challenges from both sides.

stories.headline: Federal prosecutors confirm they may drop Boeing criminal charge
stories.summary: The U.S. Department of Justice is considering a new deal that would allow Boeing to avoid a criminal fraud conviction related to its 737 MAX crashes six years ago. Federal prosecutors are reportedly in talks about a nonprosecution agreement requiring Boeing to pay a fine and improve compliance, but with no guilty plea. Victims' families have expressed outrage, fearing the deal could let Boeing off too easily, while prosecutors aim to hold the company accountable.

stories.headline: Study finds broad support for amphitheater
stories.summary: A study commissioned by Santa Fe city and county found that three-quarters of those surveyed support building a new amphitheater venue. The proposed facility could generate hundreds of millions in revenue over 10 years and attract popular outdoor music acts. Promoter Jamie Lenfestey advocates for a new medium-sized venue to replace the aging Paolo Soleri Amphitheater, highlighting a demand for more music events in the region.

stories.headline: S.F. Human Rights Alliance launches new LGBTQ+ Center
stories.summary: The Santa Fe Human Rights Alliance, led by Kevin Bowen, has opened a new LGBTQ+ Center to expand services for queer communities affected by recent political challenges to LGBTQ+ rights. The center will serve as a hub for community aid and coordinate events like Pride festivities. Funding was secured through an anonymous benefactor for a three-year lease on the center's location on Parkway Drive.

stories.headline: Lessons from the best
stories.summary: Santa Fe Public Schools honored their 'Teachers Who Inspire' winners who shared how they shape young minds through innovative teaching methods. One featured teacher, Megan Bowers Avina of Milagro Middle School, incorporates various art media and unique projects that students find engaging and empowering. The awards aim to recognize educators who uplift students and help unlock their potential to graduate.

stories.headline: Biden has aggressive prostate cancer
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with an aggressive form of prostate cancer that has spread to his bones. Biden and his family are currently reviewing treatment options. Despite the diagnosis, Biden's prognosis is considered manageable, though it raises challenges for his political future amid the 2024 election.

stories.headline: With no GOP candidate, primary likely to determine Philly’s next DA
stories.summary: The upcoming Democratic primary in Philadelphia is expected to decide the next District Attorney after no Republican candidate filed. Incumbent Larry Krasner, endorsed by progressive groups, faces a challenge from Municipal Court Judge Patrick Dugan, with high interest in the race from voters and political observers.

stories.headline: Fearing deportation, parents are pulling children from school
stories.summary: Parents of undocumented immigrants in South Jersey are pulling their children from schools due to fears of deportation amid ICE crackdowns. Advocates highlight protective measures to keep children safe, as immigrant families worry about potential family separation and arrests.

stories.headline: Shapiro’s travel in helicopter of CEO draws fire
stories.summary: Pennsylvania Governor Josh Shapiro has faced criticism for taking trips worth nearly $68,000 on a luxury helicopter owned by billionaire Michael Rubin. Critics argue such travel should not be permitted, raising ethical concerns and questions from lawmakers and public watchdogs.

stories.headline: Pope Leo XIV calls for unity in inauguration
stories.summary: Pope Leo XIV celebrated Mass during the formal inauguration of his pontificate in St. Peter's Square. His message emphasized unity, economic prudence, and the need to end hatred, violence, and prejudice, calling for a new paradigm that utilizes Earth's resources responsibly.

stories.headline: Biden has aggressive cancer
stories.summary: Former president Joe Biden has been diagnosed with a relatively aggressive form of prostate cancer, which has spread to the bone but is treatable. His family is deciding on treatment options as the cancer is hormone-sensitive. The diagnosis comes amid political challenges and debates about Biden's 2024 presidential campaign.

stories.headline: $1.6M from grant went to late taxes
stories.summary: A California-based developer spent about $1.6 million of a $5 million taxpayer-funded grant to pay off back taxes owed to Oakland County on a property that's long been an eyesore alongside Interstate 696 in Southfield. But using state tax dollars to pay off county-level property taxes didn't prevent the former Embassy Suites in Southfield from falling into receivership earlier this year and being put up for sale in the coming months. As of June 2024, developer Michael Collier's firm, Pivot Development, had spent about $2.3 million of the $5 million no-bid grant sponsored in 2023 by state officials. The former Embassy Suites in Southfield is being put up for sale in the coming weeks.

stories.headline: Biden diagnosed with prostate cancer
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, his office said Sunday. The finding came after the 82-year-old reported urinary symptoms, which led doctors to discover a nodule on his prostate. He was diagnosed on Friday, with the cancer cells having spread to the bone. The cancer appears to be a more aggressive form, hormone-sensitive, which allows for effective management according to his office. The President and his family are reviewing treatment options with his physicians. Prostate cancers are graded for aggressiveness using a Gleason score. The score ranges from 6 to 10, with scores from 6 to 8 meaning less aggressive, and 9 to 10 being the most aggressive form. When prostate cancer spreads, it often reaches the bones which makes it difficult to fully eradicate. Although prostate cancers need hormones to grow, they can be susceptible to treatment that deprives the tumors of hormones. Recent decades have seen improved outcomes for patients with metastatic prostate cancer.

stories.headline: Oakland Mall plays up fun amid retail challenges
stories.summary: When Mario Kiezi purchased Oakland Mall in 2022, he did so with bold ideas and a vision for the future. The 1.5-million-square-foot shopping center was to become "a mall of the people," a space for the next generation of families. Three years later, the results are beginning to show, though it's been a mix of wins and challenges. The mall suffered a major setback this year with the closure of Macy's, one of the longstanding anchor stores at the shopping center, which opened in 1968. Still, Kiezi of Troy-based MKiezi Investments LLC remains focused on transforming the mall into a hub for diverse shopping and immersive, family-friendly experiences. One of the most recent additions is GEMU, an 8,000-square-foot indoor playground and clawcade developed by Grace Chen and her daughter, Wen Chen, of Shelby Township. GEMU opened recently and aims to create a family-centric atmosphere.

stories.headline: Tariff era sharpens focus on auto ties
stories.summary: Auto supplier sentiment on relationships with Ford Motor Co., Chrysler parent Stellantis NV and Nissan Motor Co. Ltd. dropped year-over-year — results that could challenge the automakers' ability in navigating shifting trade policies and their impacts on supply chains, researchers said. Accounting firm Plante & Moran PLLC released its 25th annual Working Relations Index that surveyed 665 executives from 398 Tier 1 suppliers from mid-February to mid-April. That came amid changes President Donald Trump was making on tariffs, particularly on Canada and Mexico. He has since then instituted 25% duties on imported vehicles and certain auto parts. Researchers said an ability to collaborate and communicate with suppliers, including companies like General Motors Co., Toyota Motor Corp. and Honda Motor Co. Ltd., saw increases in their supplier sentiment as they worked through potential disruptions and challenges.

stories.headline: State Republicans call for unity
stories.summary: Some of Wisconsin's top Republicans urged unity at the state Republican convention amid ongoing infighting within the party. U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson warned that the GOP cannot win elections without closing party divisions. U.S. Rep. Derrick Van Orden emphasized the need to stop internal squabbles, attributing the candidate's poor showing in April to the divisions. There were direct calls for unity among Republican delegates gathered just south of Wausau, Wisconsin.

stories.headline: MPS again tardy on financial reports
stories.summary: Milwaukee Public Schools has once again missed deadlines for submitting key financial reports, increasing the risk of a state funding suspension. The district failed to meet corrective action plan due dates of May 16 and 30 after previous issues nearly caused a funding freeze last year. State officials confirmed that the department had issued a notice to withhold aid if items were not received by May 16, but the district allegedly failed to comply on time. The ongoing delays come amid resignations of top district officials and continued scrutiny from the state Department of Public Instruction.

stories.headline: Hunt grows for Indigenous woman last seen in March
stories.summary: Efforts continue to find Melissa Beson, an Indigenous woman last seen in March who has been missing in the Lac du Flambeau Reservation area in northern Wisconsin. Tribal Police Chief TJ Bill has been working overnight to assist the family, although they have yet to find any clues about her whereabouts. Rescue efforts have involved drones, a scent dog, and AI scans to search the woods near where she vanished. The case is part of a larger pattern of disappearances in the region, with multiple cases typically resolved only after long periods of searching.

stories.headline: Biden diagnosed with aggressive prostate cancer
stories.summary: Former President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, which his office says is treatable and the condition is hormone-sensitive enabling effective management. The cancer was found during a routine exam and is characterized as aggressive but with positive prognosis options. Biden and his family are reviewing treatment options, and health officials highlight that the cancer's spread represents a more aggressive disease form but is manageable with current therapies.

stories.headline: Trump’s clash with the courts raises prospect of showdown over separation of powers
stories.summary: Despite complying with most court rulings, the Trump administration continues to push boundaries, raising concerns about separation of powers. The Republican-controlled U.S. House has passed a bill curtailing the government’s ability to enforce contempt findings. The Senate is expected to address whether courts can uphold contempt in the face of executive resistance, highlighting an ongoing struggle between branches over judicial authority and executive compliance.

stories.headline: Legislature sets PFD at $1,000
stories.summary: The Alaska Legislature set this year’s Permanent Fund dividend at $1,000 per recipient, marking the lowest figure when adjusted for inflation since the program started in 1982. The decision comes amid a severe budget crunch caused by diminished oil prices, leading to spending cuts and a smaller dividend. The committee's approved $1,000 dividend though lower than the previous $1,400, followed a Senate spending plan and sought to balance budget considerations with public expectations.

stories.headline: City neighborhood fights food-desert status after the closure of a historic grocery store
stories.summary: Residents of the Fairview neighborhood near downtown Anchorage are fighting to protect their access to grocery stores and pharmacies after the historic Carrs on Gambell Street closed this month, leaving an empty, boarded-up building. Without local access and limited car ownership, residents support a program that provides shuttles to nearby stores and are pushing for the former store site to be reactivated as a grocery store, even if on a smaller scale.

stories.headline: Hundreds of volunteers lend a hand after Friday's storm
stories.summary: In the aftermath of Friday's devastating tornado in St. Louis, hundreds of volunteers from community hubs and complex services came together to assist with cleanup efforts. Groups coordinated to provide food, water, and essential supplies while aiding neighborhoods severely affected by power outages and debris. Volunteers also provided emotional support and counseling to residents recovering from the storm's impact.
people: Annie Malone Children and Family Services

stories.headline: Israel to allow limited aid into Gaza
stories.summary: Israel announced it will permit a limited amount of humanitarian aid into Gaza after nearly three months of blockade aimed at avoiding a hunger crisis amid ongoing military conflicts. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated the decision was to allow a "basic" amount of food into the territory to address worsening famine conditions warned by experts. However, the military clarified the move was not immediate and conditional amid ongoing operations near Gaza.

stories.headline: Financial aid mix-up at SIUE costs area family
stories.summary: A Southern Illinois University Edwardsville (SIUE) family encountered a financial aid issue where inaccurate information led to an unexpected bill of $17,500 for completed courses. The family had accepted grants and scholarships but were surprised by a requirement to repay funds due to incorrect data. SIUE explained that a mix-up in their Free Application for Federal Student Aid and FAFSA information caused delays and glitches in determining financial aid packages for families in need.

stories.headline: Damage prompts school changes
stories.summary: The School District of Clayton announced the closure of several schools on Monday following extensive tornado damage to buildings and surrounding streets. Captain Elementary and Wydown Middle schools remained without power and streets were still cluttered with debris. University City High and Jackson Park Elementary were also closed due to ongoing power outages in nearby neighborhoods. The district assured parents that they are working closely with staff to support students during recovery.

stories.headline: Biden found to have prostate cancer
stories.summary: President Joe Biden has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, according to sources. The cancer was discovered following tests revealing urinary symptoms and a prostate nodule. The type of prostate cancer is more aggressive, but it is localized and treatable, with metastasis less likely. Biden and his family are reviewing treatment options while continuing his official duties.

stories.headline: Science helps set free man in baby's death
stories.summary: Reginald "Regi" Tanubagijo, who spent 11 years in a San Quentin prison for killing his infant foster son, was released after scientific evidence showed the baby died from shaken baby syndrome, which prosecutors previously argued the head injuries could only have resulted from abuse.
